variant.question: Which of the following is true?

options.text: A ridge is an area of high pressure, with fair weather conditions.
A ridge is an area of high pressure with frequent thunderstorms.
A trough is an area of low pressure with fair weather.
A trough is a flat pressure system.

options.text: Friction between the air and the ground

variant.question: What is “Surface wind”?

options.text: It is the airflow near to the surface that is reduced in strength by the effect of friction.
It is the airflow near to the surface that slows down due to the effect of an increase in air density.
It is the wind that results when the pressure gradient in the layer of air near to the surface is reduced by the effect of friction.
It is the wind that experiences an increase in the Coriolis effect brought about by the increase in friction near to the surface.

315/20
What does it mean?

Wind strength is 20 knots

Wind direction is from 315 degrees true
Wind strength is 20 kilometers per hour

Wind strength is 20 knots

Wind direction is towards 315 degrees magnetic
Wind strength is 20 mph

variant.question: What relationship exists between the wind at 3000 feet and the surface wind?

options.text: The wind at 3000 ft is parallel to the isobars and the surface wind direction is across the isobars toward the low pressure and the surface wind is weaker.
They have the same direction, but the surface wind is weaker, caused by friction
They are practically the same, except when eddies exist, caused by obstacles
The surface wind is veered compared to the wind at 3000 feet and is usually weaker.

Your destination aerodrome in Western Europe lies on the crest of a ridge, inland, with an elevation of 700 feet AMSL. 
 Before take-off, the METAR for your destination is: "0850Z 27015KT 0100 R29/0650 FG VV/// 03/03 Q1005"There is another aerodrome a few miles west of the destination aerodrome at an elevation of 200 feet AMSL.The METAR for this aerodrome is: "0850Z 26011KT 9999 SCT0500 05/03 Q1005".Considering this situation, what type of fog is present at the destination aerodrome and which of these statement correctly describes the dissipation of this fog?

options.text: Orographic fog; and as the temperature rises with diurnal heating, the fog is likely to lift into cloud.
Advection fog; and diurnal heating will increase the wind speed to lift the fog into a low-level layer of stratus cloud.
Radiation fog; and diurnal heating will increase the wind speed to lift the fog into a low-level layer of stratus cloud.
Advection fog; and a change of air mass is necessary to dissipate the fog.

variant.question:
Different reports of the surface wind at an aerodrome are listed below. Which of the statements best explains the variability in the reported surface wind?09:20Z METAR: 270/07 kt 
 09:20Z ATIS: 260/06 kt 
 09:20Z Aerodrome controller: 260/06 kt

options.text: At larger aerodromes, the reported surface wind is measured by an anemometer at a height of 10 m and averaged over 2 minutes for the ATIS and the aerodrome controller, but averaged over 10 minutes for the METAR.

All aerodromes average their reported surface wind over 2 minutes, but it is measured by an anemometer at 10 m above ground level for METARs and 6 m above ground level for the ATIS and aerodrome controller.

All aerodromes report the surface wind obtained from an anemometer at a height of 4 ft above ground level, but METAR surface wind are averaged over 10 minutes and ATIS and aerodrome controller surface winds are averaged over 1 minute.

The METAR surface wind is measured by an anemometer at a height of 10 m and averaged over 10 minutes, but for the ATIS aerodrome controller the wind is measured at a height of 33 m and averaged over 5 minutes.
